hook.text: You see a snake and jump before thinking. That's System One â€” fast, automatic, and often wrong.

buildup.text: Daniel Kahneman split thinking into two systems: fast intuition and slow deliberation.

discovery.text: System One handles 95% of daily decisions. System Two activates only when things get complex.

twist.text: System One feels confident even when it's wrong. Speed creates an illusion of accuracy.

climax.text: Knowing which system is running helps you catch errors before they become costly mistakes.

punchline.text: Fast thinking feels right. Slow thinking checks.

quiz.question: What percentage of daily decisions does System One handle?
options: About 95%
About 50%
About 20%

hook.text: Classical economics assumed humans are perfectly rational. Herbert Simon proved that was fiction.

buildup.text: Simon argued that brains have limited time, information, and processing power for any given choice.

discovery.text: He called this bounded rationality: we're rational within limits, not without them.

twist.text: This means most decisions aren't optimal. They're satisfactory â€” good enough given the constraints.

climax.text: Simon won the Nobel Prize for showing that real decisions happen under fog, not spotlight.

punchline.text: Perfect decisions are a myth. Good enough is real.

quiz.question: What is bounded rationality?
options: Rationality limited by time, information, and processing power
A theory that humans are perfectly logical
A decision-making app

topics.title: The Role of Emotion in Decisions

hook.text: A man with brain damage lost the ability to feel emotions. He also lost the ability to decide.

buildup.text: Antonio Damasio studied patients with damaged emotional centers. They could reason but not choose.

discovery.text: Damasio proposed the somatic marker hypothesis: emotions tag options with gut feelings that guide choice.

twist.text: Pure logic isn't enough. Without emotional input, even choosing where to eat becomes impossible.

climax.text: Good decisions use both logic and emotion. Ignoring either one produces worse outcomes.

punchline.text: Emotions aren't the enemy of good decisions. They're part of them.

quiz.question: What did Damasio's research reveal about decision-making?
options: Emotions are essential for making choices
Logic alone produces the best decisions
Emotions always lead to poor choices

hook.text: Do you buy the first decent pair of shoes, or visit every store to find the absolute best?

buildup.text: Herbert Simon coined satisficing: accepting the first option that meets your minimum criteria.

discovery.text: Barry Schwartz found that maximizers â€” people who always seek the best â€” are less happy with their choices.

twist.text: Maximizers get objectively better outcomes but feel worse. The search itself creates regret.

climax.text: Satisficing saves time, energy, and emotional pain. Good enough really is good enough.

punchline.text: The best choice is often the first good one.

quiz.question: What did Barry Schwartz find about maximizers?
options: They get better outcomes but feel less happy
They are always happier with their choices
They make decisions faster than satisficers

hook.text: By evening, even choosing what to eat for dinner feels exhausting. Your decision tank is empty.

buildup.text: Every choice depletes a shared mental resource. The more decisions you make, the worse they get.

discovery.text: Baumeister's studies showed judges granted parole at 65% early in the day but nearly 0% by afternoon.

twist.text: Decision fatigue doesn't just lower quality. It leads to avoidance â€” choosing not to choose.

climax.text: Automating routine decisions and scheduling big choices for the morning protects your best thinking.

punchline.text: Make the big calls early. Save the easy ones for later.

quiz.question: What happens to decision quality as the day progresses?
options: It declines as mental resources deplete
It improves with practice
It stays constant throughout the day

hook.text: You think your team will win. So you notice every good play and ignore every bad one.

buildup.text: Confirmation bias means seeking information that supports what you already believe.

discovery.text: Peter Wason demonstrated this in 1960. People test hypotheses by looking for confirming evidence only.

twist.text: The bias strengthens with emotional investment. The more you care, the blinder you become.

climax.text: Actively seeking disconfirming evidence is the most effective antidote. Ask: what would prove me wrong?

punchline.text: We don't search for truth. We search for agreement.

quiz.question: What is confirmation bias?
options: Seeking information that supports existing beliefs
Changing beliefs based on new evidence
Ignoring all information equally

hook.text: A car dealer lists a car at $30,000. You negotiate down to $25,000 and feel smart. The car is worth $20,000.

buildup.text: Anchoring occurs when the first number you hear influences all subsequent judgments.

discovery.text: Tversky and Kahneman showed that even random numbers affect estimates of unrelated quantities.

twist.text: Knowing about anchoring doesn't fully protect you. The effect persists even when people are warned.

climax.text: In negotiations, the person who names the first number often controls the final outcome.

punchline.text: The first number sets the game. Choose it wisely.

quiz.question: What is the anchoring effect?
options: The first number heard influences all later judgments
People always choose the lowest option
Decisions improve with more anchors

hook.text: You sit through a terrible movie because you paid for the ticket. The money is gone either way.

buildup.text: The sunk cost fallacy means continuing something because of what you already invested, not future value.

discovery.text: Rational decisions should ignore past costs. Only future benefits and costs matter.

twist.text: The Concorde jet kept flying despite losses because two governments refused to admit the project failed.

climax.text: Letting go of sunk costs feels like losing. But holding on guarantees bigger losses.

punchline.text: Don't cling to a mistake because you spent time making it.

quiz.question: What is the sunk cost fallacy?
options: Continuing something because of past investment, not future value
Always abandoning projects early
Investing only in guaranteed outcomes

hook.text: Losing $100 hurts about twice as much as gaining $100 feels good. The brain hates losing.

buildup.text: Kahneman and Tversky proved that humans feel losses roughly twice as strongly as equivalent gains.

discovery.text: This asymmetry explains why people avoid risks even when the expected payoff is positive.

twist.text: Companies exploit loss aversion constantly. Free trials work because canceling feels like losing.

climax.text: Recognizing loss aversion helps you take smarter risks instead of clinging to the safe default.

punchline.text: Fear of loss makes us lose more opportunities.

quiz.question: How strongly do humans feel losses compared to equivalent gains?
options: About twice as strongly
About equally
About half as strongly

hook.text: A bank robber covered his face with lemon juice, believing it made him invisible to cameras.

buildup.text: David Dunning and Justin Kruger found that the least skilled people overestimate their ability most.

discovery.text: Incompetence creates a double burden: poor performance and the inability to recognize it.

twist.text: Experts often underestimate themselves. More knowledge reveals how much you still don't know.

climax.text: The cure is feedback from others. External mirrors show what internal confidence distorts.

punchline.text: The less you know, the more certain you feel.

quiz.question: What does the Dunning-Kruger effect describe?
options: Least skilled people overestimate their ability most
Experts are always the most confident
Everyone estimates their skills equally

hook.text: You choose a restaurant by how busy it looks. That shortcut saves time but can mislead.

buildup.text: Heuristics are mental shortcuts the brain uses to make quick judgments without full analysis.

discovery.text: Tversky and Kahneman identified dozens of heuristics that guide everyday thinking.

twist.text: Heuristics work most of the time. But in unfamiliar situations, the shortcuts produce systematic errors.

climax.text: The key isn't avoiding heuristics. It's knowing when to override them with slower analysis.

punchline.text: Shortcuts save time until they cost you.

quiz.question: What are heuristics?
options: Mental shortcuts for quick judgments
Detailed analytical methods
Mathematical formulas for decisions

hook.text: After seeing a plane crash on the news, you feel flying is dangerous. You drove to the airport safely.

buildup.text: The availability heuristic judges probability by how easily examples come to mind.

discovery.text: Vivid, recent, or emotional events feel more common than they actually are.

twist.text: Media amplifies this. Shark attacks get headlines; heart disease doesn't. Fear follows coverage, not data.

climax.text: Checking actual statistics before reacting overrides the heuristic and improves risk assessment.

punchline.text: What's memorable isn't always what's probable.

quiz.question: How does the availability heuristic judge probability?
options: By how easily examples come to mind
By careful statistical analysis
By consulting multiple experts

hook.text: Linda is outspoken and studied philosophy. Is she more likely a bank teller or a feminist bank teller?

buildup.text: Most people say feminist bank teller. That's mathematically impossible â€” the subset can't exceed the set.

discovery.text: The representativeness heuristic judges probability by how much something resembles a stereotype.

twist.text: This shortcut ignores base rates. Rare categories get inflated because they fit the story better.

climax.text: Asking about base rates before judging â€” how common is this category? â€” corrects the error.

punchline.text: A good story isn't the same as a likely one.

quiz.question: What does the representativeness heuristic do?
options: Judges probability by resemblance to a stereotype
Calculates exact probabilities
Always produces correct answers

hook.text: You feel good about solar energy, so you rate its risks as low and its benefits as high. Feeling drove logic.

buildup.text: The affect heuristic means emotions about a subject shape your judgment of its risks and benefits.

discovery.text: Paul Slovic showed that people who like a technology downplay its risks and inflate its gains.

twist.text: The reverse also holds. Dislike something and you'll overestimate danger, even without evidence.

climax.text: Separating how you feel from what you know is the hardest â€” and most important â€” decision skill.

punchline.text: Feelings color facts before you notice.

quiz.question: What does the affect heuristic describe?
options: Emotions shaping risk and benefit judgments
Using data to override all feelings
Making decisions without any emotion

hook.text: Most people never change their phone's default settings. The default wins by doing nothing.

buildup.text: Status quo bias means people prefer the current state of affairs, even when better options exist.

discovery.text: Organ donation rates soar in countries where the default is opt-in. The form design decides who lives.

twist.text: The bias isn't laziness. It's loss aversion in disguise â€” changing feels like losing the current option.

climax.text: Designing better defaults is one of the most powerful tools in behavioral economics.

punchline.text: The default option almost always wins.

quiz.question: Why do people tend to stick with the status quo?
options: Change feels like losing the current option
The current state is always the best
People carefully analyze all alternatives first

hook.text: President Kennedy's advisors all agreed the Bay of Pigs invasion would succeed. It was a disaster.

buildup.text: Irving Janis coined groupthink: when a group values consensus so much that critical thinking dies.

discovery.text: Symptoms include overconfidence, suppressed dissent, and illusions of unanimity.

twist.text: Smart people in groups make worse decisions than they would alone when conformity pressure is high.

climax.text: Assigning a devil's advocate or using anonymous input breaks the groupthink cycle.

punchline.text: Agreement feels good. It can also be dangerous.

quiz.question: Who coined the term groupthink?
options: Irving Janis
Daniel Kahneman
Herbert Simon

hook.text: Ask one person to guess a cow's weight and they'll be way off. Average 800 guesses and it's eerily precise.

buildup.text: James Surowiecki's book showed that diverse, independent groups outperform individual experts.

discovery.text: The wisdom of crowds works when opinions are independent, diverse, decentralized, and aggregated.

twist.text: Remove independence â€” let people see each other's answers â€” and the wisdom collapses into herding.

climax.text: Smart group decisions require structure. Without it, crowds become mobs, not oracles.

punchline.text: Crowds are wise only when each voice thinks alone.

quiz.question: What conditions make the wisdom of crowds work?
options: Independence, diversity, decentralization, and aggregation
Everyone agreeing on the same answer
A single expert guiding the group

hook.text: A family drives 50 miles in the heat to Abilene. Nobody wanted to go. Nobody said so.

buildup.text: Jerry Harvey described this in 1974: groups often agree on actions nobody actually wants.

discovery.text: Each person assumes the others want it. Fear of rocking the boat creates false consensus.

twist.text: The Abilene Paradox is the opposite of groupthink. Everyone privately disagrees but publicly conforms.

climax.text: Simply asking does anyone actually want this can prevent hours of wasted collective effort.

punchline.text: Silence isn't agreement. It's often the opposite.

quiz.question: What is the Abilene Paradox?
options: Groups agreeing on actions nobody actually wants
Groups always making the best decision
Individuals making better choices than groups

hook.text: You pass two restaurants. One is empty, one has a line. You join the line. Everyone else did too.

buildup.text: Social proof means using other people's behavior as evidence for what's correct.

discovery.text: Robert Cialdini showed that hotel guests reuse towels far more when told most other guests do.

twist.text: Social proof can be manufactured. Fake reviews, inflated follower counts, and paid lines all exploit it.

climax.text: The shortcut works well in stable environments but fails when the crowd itself is misinformed.

punchline.text: Following the crowd saves time until it doesn't.

quiz.question: What is social proof?
options: Using others' behavior as evidence for what's correct
Proving your social status to others
A legal term for group contracts

hook.text: Kitty Genovese was attacked while 38 neighbors watched. Nobody called the police.

buildup.text: Diffusion of responsibility means that in a group, each person assumes someone else will act.

discovery.text: Darley and Latane proved this in labs. The more bystanders present, the less likely anyone helps.

twist.text: The fix is simple: assign responsibility directly. Pointing at one person and saying you, call 911 works.

climax.text: In teams, unnamed tasks belong to nobody. Explicit ownership is the cure for diffusion.

punchline.text: Everyone's job becomes nobody's job.

quiz.question: What causes diffusion of responsibility?
options: Each person assumes someone else will act
Too few people are present
People are trained to never intervene

hook.text: Imagine your project has already failed. Now work backward to figure out why. That's a pre-mortem.

buildup.text: Gary Klein developed this technique. It flips optimism into productive paranoia.

discovery.text: Research shows pre-mortems increase the ability to identify risks by 30% compared to standard planning.

twist.text: It also gives permission to voice doubts. In normal planning, criticism feels disloyal.

climax.text: The best time to find a fatal flaw is before you launch, not after the wreckage.

punchline.text: Plan for failure before it plans for you.

quiz.question: What is a pre-mortem analysis?
options: Imagining a project has failed and working backward to find causes
Reviewing a project after it has actually failed
Celebrating success before a project launches

hook.text: A city builds more roads to reduce traffic. More people drive. Traffic gets worse. Second-order effects.

buildup.text: First-order thinking asks: what happens next? Second-order asks: and then what happens after that?

discovery.text: Howard Marks calls this the mark of a superior thinker: going beyond the obvious first reaction.

twist.text: Most policy failures come from ignoring second-order effects. The cure often creates the next disease.

climax.text: Training yourself to ask and then what three times reveals consequences invisible to first-order minds.

punchline.text: First-order thinkers react. Second-order thinkers anticipate.

quiz.question: What does second-order thinking involve?
options: Considering the consequences of consequences
Only thinking about the immediate next step
Ignoring all long-term effects

hook.text: Jeff Bezos splits decisions into two types: one-way doors and two-way doors.

buildup.text: One-way doors are irreversible. Two-way doors can be undone. Most decisions are two-way doors.

discovery.text: Bezos argues that two-way door decisions should be made fast. Only one-way doors deserve deep analysis.

twist.text: Most organizations treat every decision like a one-way door. Caution slows everything to a crawl.

climax.text: Speed on reversible decisions and care on irreversible ones is the optimal decision strategy.

punchline.text: Most doors swing both ways. Walk through faster.

quiz.question: How does Jeff Bezos classify decisions?
options: One-way doors and two-way doors based on reversibility
Easy and hard based on complexity
Fast and slow based on time needed

hook.text: Before deciding, ask: how will I feel about this in 10 minutes, 10 months, and 10 years?

buildup.text: Suzy Welch created this framework to escape the tyranny of short-term emotions.

discovery.text: The rule forces time-perspective shifting. What feels urgent now often vanishes in the 10-year view.

twist.text: It also catches the opposite: decisions that feel fine now but create pain for your future self.

climax.text: The best decisions balance all three timeframes. Ignoring any one of them creates blind spots.

punchline.text: Zoom out before you decide.

quiz.question: What does the 10-10-10 Rule ask you to consider?
options: How you'll feel in 10 minutes, 10 months, and 10 years
Ten alternative options for every decision
The opinions of ten different people

hook.text: Charlie Munger says: tell me where I'm going to die, so I never go there.

buildup.text: Inversion thinking flips the problem. Instead of asking how to succeed, ask how to guarantee failure.

discovery.text: Carl Jacobi, a mathematician, used this method: invert, always invert. Solve problems backward.

twist.text: Avoiding stupidity is easier and more reliable than seeking brilliance. Inversion targets the former.

climax.text: List everything that would make a project fail. Then do the opposite. Simple and powerful.

punchline.text: Avoid the worst outcomes. The good ones find you.

quiz.question: What is inversion thinking?
options: Solving problems by considering how to guarantee failure first
Always following the most popular approach
Making decisions purely based on intuition

hook.text: Two Israeli psychologists walked together for hours, laughing and arguing. They changed economics forever.

buildup.text: Kahneman and Tversky spent decades mapping the systematic errors in human judgment.

discovery.text: Their prospect theory showed that people evaluate gains and losses differently â€” losses hurt more.

twist.text: Economists resisted for years. Rational actor theory was sacred. Data eventually won the argument.

climax.text: Kahneman won the Nobel Prize in 2002. Tversky had died six years earlier and couldn't share it.

punchline.text: Two friends rewrote how the world understands decisions.

quiz.question: What did Kahneman and Tversky's prospect theory show?
options: People evaluate gains and losses differently
All decisions are perfectly rational
Emotions play no role in economics

hook.text: A fly painted inside a urinal at Amsterdam airport reduced spillage by 80%. That's a nudge.

buildup.text: Richard Thaler and Cass Sunstein showed that small design changes steer decisions without force.

discovery.text: Nudges preserve freedom of choice while making the better option easier to select.

twist.text: Critics call it paternalistic. Supporters say we're always being nudged â€” better to nudge wisely.

climax.text: Thaler won the Nobel Prize in 2017. Nudge units now operate in governments worldwide.

punchline.text: Tiny design changes shape millions of decisions.

quiz.question: What is a nudge in behavioral economics?
options: A small design change that steers decisions without force
A mandatory rule that removes choice
A financial penalty for bad decisions

hook.text: A firefighter enters a burning building and suddenly orders everyone out. Seconds later, the floor collapses.

buildup.text: Gary Klein studied how experts make split-second decisions in chaotic, real-world environments.

discovery.text: He found experts don't compare options. They recognize patterns from experience and act immediately.

twist.text: This contradicts lab-based decision theory. In the field, intuition often outperforms analysis.

climax.text: Klein's Recognition-Primed Decision model shows that experience builds a mental library of patterns.

punchline.text: Experts don't calculate. They recognize.

quiz.question: How do experts make decisions in chaotic environments according to Klein?
options: They recognize patterns from experience
They carefully compare all options
They always defer to written procedures

hook.text: A doctor using one simple question diagnosed heart attacks better than a complex algorithm.

buildup.text: Gerd Gigerenzer argues that simple heuristics often outperform complex models in uncertain worlds.

discovery.text: His fast-and-frugal heuristics use minimal information. Less data, better decisions â€” counterintuitive but proven.

twist.text: Complex models overfit to noise. Simple rules focus on the one or two factors that actually matter.

climax.text: Gigerenzer's work shows that real-world intelligence isn't about more data. It's about the right data.

punchline.text: Sometimes less information makes smarter choices.

quiz.question: What does Gigerenzer argue about simple heuristics?
options: They often outperform complex models in uncertain environments
They always produce worse results than algorithms
They only work in laboratory settings

topics.title: The Trolley Problem and Moral Decisions

hook.text: A trolley is heading toward five people. You can divert it to kill one instead. What do you choose?

buildup.text: Philippa Foot introduced this thought experiment in 1967. It still divides ethicists today.

discovery.text: Brain scans show moral dilemmas activate both emotional and rational centers simultaneously.

twist.text: Changing the scenario slightly â€” pushing someone off a bridge instead â€” flips most people's answers.

climax.text: The trolley problem reveals that moral decisions aren't purely logical. Context and emotion shape ethics.

punchline.text: Moral choices are never just math problems.

quiz.question: What does the trolley problem reveal about moral decisions?
options: Context and emotion shape ethical choices
People always choose to save the most lives
Moral decisions are purely logical
